Summary: The proposal introduces a methodology for next-generation AI benchmark design, focusing on bias-aware dataset construction, dynamic benchmarking, and evaluation protocol standardization. It includes a detailed experiment plan to validate synthetic data utility, deploy dynamic benchmarking, and assess multi-dimensional metrics, with real-world deployment goals.
Strengths: Clear and well-articulated problem statement with strong motivation.
Comprehensive methodology addressing multiple aspects of benchmark design.
Detailed and systematic experiment plan with real-world deployment goals.
Strong scientific rigor with multi-dimensional metrics and pre-registration support.
Weaknesses: Lacks concrete details on synthetic data generation and validation.
Feasibility of large-scale dynamic adversarial filtering needs further justification.
Potential challenges in community adoption and integration with existing benchmarks.
Limited discussion on potential biases introduced by synthetic data generation.
Questions: How will synthetic data be generated to ensure it accurately reflects real-world complexity?
What specific mechanisms will be used to implement adversarial filtering at scale?
How will the proposed benchmarks ensure compatibility with existing model training pipelines?
What measures will be taken to mitigate bias in synthetic data generation?
Limitations: Potential difficulty in achieving widespread adoption of new benchmarks.
Risk of synthetic data not fully capturing real-world distribution shifts.
Challenges in maintaining dynamic benchmarks over time.
Scalability of dynamic benchmarking across diverse tasks.
